text:
*Degassing viscous solutions for clearing/imaging*

I have started using CUBIC for clearing mouse eyes using a protocol from this paper (<https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8374524/>).

I have only degassed once before about 5 years ago in my PhD and I bubbled nitrogen through the solution (one of the X-CLARITY ones) in a Falcon tube for 5-10 minutes and then quickly sealed the lid afterwards. I think the idea is to remove all microbubbles for imaging quality?

My question is, how do other people do degassing? Is it sufficient to leave the solution on the side for a week? I have been using CUBIC-2 to image in as the alternative is even more expensive immersion media oils and this is just a test project at the moment.

I will post my efforts in the protocols channel.

attachments.fallback: PubMed Central (PMC): InVision: An optimized tissue clearing approach for three-dimensional imaging and analysis of intact rodent eyes
attachments.text: The mouse eye is used to model central nervous system development, pathology, angiogenesis, tumorigenesis, and regenerative therapies. To facilitate the analysis of these processes, we developed an optimized tissue clearing and depigmentation protocol, ...
attachments.title: InVision: An optimized tissue clearing approach for three-dimensional imaging and analysis of intact rodent eyes
